channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Inside Amazon, Diversity Concerns Flare Up After Harassment Accusations
item.media:description: Like other technology companies, Amazon has described improving the diversity of its work force as an important company goal.
item.media:credit: Stuart Isett for The New York Times
item.description: Amazon’s handling of accusations of sexual harassment involving Roy Price, who ran its movie and television operations, has set off confusion, debate and finger-pointing.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Feature: How the Appetite for Emojis Complicates the Effort to Standardize the World’s Alphabets
item.description: Do the volunteers behind Unicode, whose mission is to bring all human languages into the digital sphere, have enough bandwidth to deal with emojis too?
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL ERARD

item.title: Meet the People Who Will Defend Google, Facebook and Twitter Before Lawmakers
item.media:description: Google, Facebook and Twitter are sending in their general counsels to testify at congressional hearings on Nov. 1.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: The internet companies are putting their general counsels in the hot seats in front of lawmakers on Nov. 1.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG and DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Bits: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Regulation Is Looming
item.description: In this week’s tech newsletter, the tech giants battle Washington’s regulatory fervor. Also, Lyft gets a lot of money, and Google may remake Toronto.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Russia’s Favored Outlet Is an Online News Giant. YouTube Helped.
item.media:description: Robert Kyncl, left, a YouTube executive, helped RT celebrate reaching one billion views on the video service in 2013.
item.description: RT was early to embrace the video site. Now that relationship is drawing scrutiny as investigators look into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Amazon Counts Its Suitors: 238 Want to Be Home for 2nd Headquarters
item.media:description: Mayor Ras J. Baraka of Newark, center, with New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, left, and Senator Cory Booker. The city and state are offering up to $7 billion in tax breaks for Amazon’s new headquarters.
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: The bidders came from 43 U.S. states, as well as Canada and Mexico. Amazon says the project will create 50,000 jobs, and that the winner will be announced next year.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Reading This While Walking? In Honolulu, It Could Cost You
item.media:description: Pedestrians on Hotel Street at Fort Street Mall in Honolulu. Honolulu enacted a law, set to take effect Wednesday, that allows the police to fine pedestrians up to $35 for viewing their electronic devices while crossing streets in the city and surrounding county.
item.media:credit: Marco Garcia for The New York Times
item.description: The city has passed a law designed to protect pedestrians staring at their smartphones from themselves. But critics say engineering and redesigning streets would be more effective.
item.dc:creator: TANYA MOHN

item.title: Tech Tip: New Windows for the Fall Season
item.description: Microsoft’s second major Windows 10 update was released last week and may already be installed on your computer.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: B Capital Hires Howard L. Morgan as Its New Chairman
item.media:description: Howard L. Morgan in 2012
item.description: The venture capital fund taps a veteran of the start-up world as it looks to broaden its scope beyond Silicon Valley and China.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Advertising: With Literary Support, Xerox Asserts Its Modern Relevance
item.media:description: The author Gary Shteyngart used a voice-activated printer to write his essay for Xerox’s “Set the Page Free” project.
item.description: Xerox, in collaboration with the 92nd Street Y, gathered essays from writers like Gary Shteyngart and Joyce Carol Oates to help reinforce its role in the workplace.
item.dc:creator: MATT KRUPNICK

item.title: Tech Giants Are Paying Huge Salaries for Scarce A.I. Talent
item.media:description: Luke Zettlemoyer, a professor at the University of Washington, at a campus library. He turned down a lucrative offer from Google, instead taking a post at the nonprofit Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence so he could continue teaching.
item.media:credit: Kyle Johnson for The New York Times
item.description: Nearly all big tech companies have an artificial intelligence project, and they are willing to pay experts millions of dollars to help get it done.
item.dc:creator: CADE METZ

item.title: A Showdown Brews Between Amazon and Alibaba, Far From Home
item.media:description: The RedMart warehouse in Singapore. The online grocery is part of Alibaba’s push into Southeast Asia.
item.media:credit: Lauryn Ishak for The New York Times
item.description: The e-commerce giants are spending billions in new markets like Southeast Asia and India to tap a rising new class of young, middle-class shoppers.
item.dc:creator: JANE A. PETERSON
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: With...Susan Fowler: She’s 26, and Brought Down Uber’s C.E.O. What’s Next?
item.media:description: Susan Fowler describes herself as “an amateur myrmecologist.”
item.media:credit: Damien Maloney for The New York Times
item.description: In her first interview since the essay that started a wave of sexual-harassment revelations, Susan Fowler tells her life story and looks to the future.
item.dc:creator: MAUREEN DOWD

item.title: Confirm or Deny ... Susan Fowler
item.media:description: Susan Fowler at her home.
item.media:credit: Damien Maloney for The New York Times
item.description: The former Uber employee has deleted her account. But would she ever go back?
item.dc:creator: MAUREEN DOWD

item.title: Mind: How Fiction Becomes Fact on Social Media
item.description: Platforms like Facebook and Twitter offer up memes designed to feel real, if only for an instant — long enough for our minds to make a false connection.
item.dc:creator: BENEDICT CAREY
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: The Woman Who Created #MeToo Long Before Hashtags
item.media:description: Tarana Burke created a nonprofit organization to help victims of sexual harassment and assault.
item.description: Tarana Burke was helping victims of sexual harassment long before Alyssa Milano’s tweet gave the movement a boost.
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA

item.title: Tech Tip: Taking Your iTunes Library to Android
item.description: Apple’s iTunes Store used to be more restrictive, but if you’ve purchased music there in the past eight years, you can play it more places.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Hundreds of Mysterious Stone ‘Gates’ Found in Saudi Arabia’s Desert
item.media:description: Using Google Earth, an archaeologist has identified nearly 400 stone structures called “gates” in Saudi Arabia. They may have been built by ancient nomadic tribes.
item.media:credit: Satellite photo by CNES/Airbus, via Google Earth
item.description: With Google Earth, archaeologists have uncovered strange stone structures that may have been built by nomadic tribes in ancient lava fields.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Lyft Is Said to Explore I.P.O. as It Raises $1 Billion Led by Alphabet
item.media:description: Lyft raised $1 billion in a new investment led by CapitalG, the venture arm of Alphabet.
item.description: The ride-hailing company is exploring a 2018 initial public offering, as it added fresh capital to its coffers from investors including a venture arm spun out of Google.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and KATIE BENNER

item.title: Trump Picks Joseph Simons, Corporate Antitrust Lawyer, to Lead F.T.C.
item.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission building in Washington. The agency is facing new skepticism over the power of big internet companies.
item.description: The choice comes at a time of broad bipartisan concern over corporate consolidation and big deals in the waiting.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG

item.title: Tech Tip: Editing Your History on Amazon
item.description: The shopping site keeps a record of the products you browse in the hope you’ll return to close the deal, but you can turn off the tracking.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Want to Clap for Xi Jinping’s Speech? Use Your Smartphone
item.media:description: A screen shot of the game in WeChat that lets users show their appreciation for President Xi Jinping of China by quickly and repeatedly tapping their phone screens.
item.description: A WeChat app lets users show appreciation for the Chinese leader’s words by mashing their screens. The game says players have clapped a billion times so far.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Senators Demand Online Ad Disclosures as Tech Lobby Mobilizes
item.media:description: Senator John McCain on Wednesday on Capitol Hill.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Tech has fought online ad regulations, but three senators will introduce a bipartisan bill to force the industry to disclose who buys political ads.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH P. VOGEL and CECILIA KANG
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Dream City?: Google’s Founders Wanted to Shape a City. Toronto Is Their Chance.
item.media:description: A rendering of the Sidewalk Labs vision for a new waterfront development in Toronto.
item.description: Here’s an opportunity to develop “the world’s first neighborhood built from the internet up,” but will humans be put first?
item.dc:creator: EMILY BADGER

item.title: Tech We’re Using: Pioneering Virtual Reality and New Video Technologies in Journalism
item.media:description: Marcelle Hopkins, deputy video editor at The Times, trying on virtual reality technology at a V.R. event this month.
item.media:credit: Danny Ghitis for The New York Times
item.description: Marcelle Hopkins, deputy video editor and co-director of virtual reality, traces The Times’s push into V.R. and other visual technologies.
item.dc:creator: MARCELLE HOPKINS

item.title: Tech Tip: Using New Space-Saving Photo Files
item.description: With the latest updates for its Macs and mobile devices, Apple has added support for new image and video formats while keeping things compatible.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Samsung Is Under Scrutiny Again as South Korean Police Raid Offices
item.media:description: Lee Kun-hee, Samsung’s patriarch, leaving a court in Seoul, South Korea, in 2008. The police are now investigating whether he misappropriated company funds to renovate his family’s home.
item.description: Two months after a scion of the conglomerate’s controlling family was sent to prison, investigators were looking into an alleged misappropriation of company funds.
item.dc:creator: JEYUP S. KWAAK

item.title: How Many People Watch Netflix? Nielsen Tries to Solve a Mystery
item.media:description: Gaten Matarazzo, left, Finn Wolfhard, Caleb McLaughlin and Noah Schnapp in the original Netflix series “Stranger Things.”
item.description: The ratings company is using audio-recognition software to crack a closely guarded trade secret.
item.dc:creator: JOHN KOBLIN

item.title: State of the Art: How the Frightful Five Put Start-Ups in a Lose-Lose Situation
item.description: In Silicon Valley, small companies used to unseat big ones. Now the clutches of the five biggest tech companies are hard to escape.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: After Drone Hits Plane in Canada, New Fears About Air Safety
item.media:description: Marc Garneau, Canada’s transport minister.
item.description: Pilots are filing reports of drones flying too high on a weekly, almost daily basis, despite new rules and fines.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Google Serves Fake News Ads in an Unlikely Place: Fact-Checking Sites
item.media:description: At the top of PolitiFact’s front page last week, a display ad served by Google promoted a fake news story that said Melania Trump was leaving the White House. It linked to a faked version of Vogue’s site.
item.description: Google placed ads linking to blatantly bogus stories on Snopes and PolitiFact, sites created precisely to dispel such falsehoods.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI and LINDA QIU

item.title: Google Maps Pulls Calorie-Counting Feature After Criticism
item.media:description: Google said the calorie feature would be removed from its map app.
item.description: The app told users how many calories they would burn by walking instead of driving, but was criticized as dangerous to people with eating disorders.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Tech Tip: Moving the Windows 10 Taskbar by Hand
item.description: Like previous versions of the system, Windows 10 lets you move the taskbar to where you want it.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Google’s Pixel 2 Smartphone Is a Powerful Extravagance
item.media:description: The Pixel 2, the new flagship phone from Google that goes on sale Thursday.
item.description: Google’s new Pixel 2 phone is clearly impressive, according to our reviewer. But whether that makes the device worth buying is another matter.
item.dc:creator: CADE METZ
